data.lead_paragraph: A single mother on welfare living in a Brooklyn apartment refused the sexual advances of her landlord. He shut off the electricity, rejected her rent check and followed her, menacingly, around the neighborhood . . . A Milwaukee landlord was ordered to pay $19,000 to a tenant after he was convicted of housing discrimination; he had demanded sex in lieu of rent . . . A young couple in Toledo faced eviction after the wife spurned the advances of their landlord. Sexual harassment is not confined to the workplace. Women in New York and other cities are increasingly vulnerable to abuse in housing, especially with the rise in poor single women and female heads of households. So vulnerable, indeed, that ''quantifying the magnitude of sexual harassment is difficult,'' according to Annette Fuentes and Madelyn Miller in City Limits, an urban affairs monthly. ''Silence born of fear and powerlessness stifles reports from victims.''
